source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Heinrich [20] reported that iron-nickel aggregates appeared to disperse in oxides on Zircaloy-2, while iron-chromium aggregates remained as separate phases, suggesting a low solubility of the Fe-Cr phase in the oxide.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Chromium rejection from the oxide appears to be a plausible source of the segregated chromium phase, consistent with an apparent general depletion of chromium in the oxide.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Copper segregation in the oxide on the Zr-Cu-Fe alloy tended to be nodular with no indication of bands associated with partings in the oxide (Fig. 17).

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Absence of Fe, Cr, or Ni in the partings on the Zr-Cu-Fe alloy further argued against crud as the source of chromium segregations in the oxide on the Zr-Cr-Fe alloy.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Heinrich [20] found uniform copper distribution in a beta-quenched Zr-2.5Nb-0.5Cu alloy having good corrosion resistance.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: A similar specimen, having had an anneal in the alpha-plus-beta region, showed an inhomogeneous copper distribution in the oxide and also showed poor corrosion resistance.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: The favorable corrosion response of the niobium alloys in as-etched and prefilmed conditions provides considerable evidence that alloying with niobium can counteract accelerated corrosion attack in aggressive reactor systems.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: The niobium alloys, particularly Zr-2.5Nb, displayed excellent resistance to hydriding.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: However, of the six alloys, only the Zr-Cu-Fe alloy showed highly unfavorable hydriding behavior, which occurred at in-flux and out-of-flux positions.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Prefilming enhanced the in-flux corrosion of 174-day high-flux Zr-Cr-Fe, Zr-Cu-Fe and Zircaloy-2 by a factor of 2 compared to corresponding as-etched specimens.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Results from another G-7 loop test [21] demonstrated that a thick prefilm oxide (~200-250 mg/dm²) can greatly accelerate in-flux corrosion, even in a system which is unaggressive toward as-etched specimens.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: On the other hand, absence of the non-uniform attack on low-flux and out-of-flux Zr-2.5Nb specimens indicates that some minimum level of flux (or fluence) is required to nucleate the nonuniform attack.

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: However, on the Zr-2.5Nb specimens, the consequences of the flux-related nucleation were only beginning to become significant at a fast-neutron fluence of 1.7×10²¹ n/cm².

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Lithiated system (300 C prefilm): 350-530 mg/dm² (dependent on Zircaloy-2 lot)

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: Ammoniated system (400 C prefilm): 220

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_022_chunk6
evidence_span: (as-etched): 120
